Let me respond "briefly to Earley’s proposal for the establishment of audience
survey service. My first reaction is negative. I think the idea is a good
one but does not r equire the setting up of a national office or the^hiring
of a full time national research director. Instead, let me suggest a
consulting service with a roster of persons on call who could go to the
localities concerned to help stations.
My objection to a full blown research operation takes the following:
a. The returns from such surveys (assuming that wealthy stations and
stations near Universities need no help) will not aupport a full time
operation.
b. The research opportunities which arise from such activity will be
negligible since I fear that the setting up of the survey will be on a
hurry-up basis and will not entail the kind of planning necessary to make
the survey much more than a sheer nose-counting procedure.
c. College and university staff members are not going to fall over
themselves to try and get one of these survey jobs. From experience, both
of us know that simply because the cause is good does not mean any kind
of research assistance particularly when the nature of the project is preset.
d. There are not enough persons interested in research who are also
interested in broadcasting to make any kind of viable organization a realistic
accomplishment*
e. No estimate of cost of s urveys is included in the proposal. My
feeling is that most stations are not willing to dish out the money to get
any decent survey done. If a simple nose-counting procedure is all they
need, why not underwrite a simple manual of how-to-do-it and sell this to
stations?
